quote: I, for one, never had a doubt. My stock in this company must have split a dozen times by now.
Actually the process of cryonics was never more than a fad, and did not continue much beyond the mid-twenty-first century.
I need to make a phone call as soon as possible.
A phone call?
I have provided for myself. I have a substantial portfolio. It's critical I check on it. Let the bank know that I am alive and well.
That's ah... going to be a little difficult right at the moment.
Do you at least have a copy of The Wall Street Journal?
I think we should take the doctor's advice and go slowly. Get adjusted to your new... ah... whatever, and then we'll talk to the captain.
As you know, there is very little available on the Romulans
Anything will help.

They seem to be creatures of extremes. One moment violent beyond description, the next -- tender. They're related to the Vulcans but as each developed, their differences grew wider. They are intensely curious. Their belief in their own superiority is beyond arrogance. For some reason they have exhibited a fascination with humans and that fascination, more than anything else, has kept the peace. One other thing, they will not initiate. They will wait for you to commit yourself.
Counterpunches... Thank you, Counselor. This is quite helpful.
I don't know about you all... but me -- I'm going to find the bar. After all of this -- I need me a drink.
There is nothing of that nature on board the Enterprise.
No bars?! Don't tell me that, son. Well, where's the restaurant? I'm so hungry.
We have food stations. (he indicates the computer) Simply tell the computer what you want and it will be provided.
Where do you eat it?
Why... here... or anywhere. We're not that structured.
Now what?
Talk.
I'd like me a thick Kansas City steak - country fried potatoes -- a mess of greens -- and... Oh, hell... forget all of that. Let me have a martini - -straight up... two olives. ... for the vitamins.
Is there something wrong?
Wrong? Only that your computer here fixed just about the best martini I have ever had. I just might get to like this place. Let's see if the Braves are on. How do you turn on this here teevee?
Teevee?
Yeah, boob-tube... you know. I'd like to find out how the Braves are doin' after all this time. Probably still finding ways to lose.
Oh -- I think he means television, sir.
Or maybe catch up on the soaps.
That particular form of entertainment did not last much beyond the year Two Thousand Forty.
So, what do you guys do? I mean, you don't drink -- no teevee -- kind of boring, isn't it?
Number One.
Riker here.
Would you and Mister Data report to the bridge?
On the way.
With whom were you speaking?
The captain.
Ah... good. Tell him I would like to see him as soon as it's convenient.
What is going to happen to us? Do we stay here with you? Do we go back to Earth?
That will be up to the captain.
Well, get him in here. I have to phone Geneva right away about my accounts. The interest alone could be enough to buy even this ship.
The Yankee's right. Let's get the big boy in here.
I'll pass on your request. Now, if you'll excuse us.
Duty calls -- hey, I understand... ... come back later -- you and me can find us a couple of low-mileage pit woffies, and help them build a memory.
What is to be done with them?
I don't know.
Commander. What is a "low-mileage-pit-woffie"?
This time you have me, Data. I haven't a clue.
These are not like any other humans I have ever encountered. I find them fascinating.
From what I have already seen of our "guests", there is very little to redeem them. In fact, it makes me wonder, how our species ever survived the twenty-first century.
Report.
We are six hours from the Neutral Zone. I have been unable to establish communications with any Federation colony or station in this vicinity.
How many outposts are there in this sector?
Nine.
I think we should go on the presumption that they've all been destroyed.
By the Romulans?
It fits their historical pattern.
Since there has been no contact with the Romulans for fifty-three years, seven months, eighteen days, we must consider that the information we do have, is out of date.
The positive side of that is their information about us is also out of date. Captain, I believe that lack of information is what this is all about.
Continue, Number One.
In my opinion, the Romulans want a confrontation... specifically against us.
The Enterprise?

Not by name; but yes, against us. They know the Federation will send their best -- this will be a perfect chance for them to learn firsthand, how much we have advanced in both technology, and technique.
And your recommendation.
I don't know if I have a specific recommendation. Perhaps we should consider taking the initiative.
I agree with Commander Riker. We may only have one opportunity; we should seize it.
Data.
That strategy is built on a single premise. The hostile intent of the Romulans. If the premise is sound, so is the proposal.
If their intention isn't hostile, what is it?
Captain Picard?
This is the captain, to whom am I speaking?
Ralph Offenhouse. Captain, I need to talk to you.
What's going on here, Number One? Did you give him permission to contact me?
No, sir. He must have seen me use the com panel.
Listen, Mister Offenhouse. We are in a very important conference right now and...
I am sick and tired of being put off by you and your staff. This is the worst run ship I have ever been on. You could take some lessons from the Q-E Two. Now that's an efficient operation.
Data -- identify -- what's the Q-E-Two?
It was a passenger liner which mostly traveled Earth's Atlantic Ocean during the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries.
He's comparing the Enterprise to a cruise ship.
I demand you see me.

... I think I have been very, very patient, especially under the circumstances and considering what I paid for this procedure, but frankly enough is enough. I demand a phone, or a radio whatever you have. I must contact my...
(continuing; off balance for a beat) ...lawyers.
I am Captain Picard.
Excellent.
Now, we'll be able to get some things straight.
Indeed we will. Those com panels are for official ship business.
If they are so important, why don't they need an "executive key"?
Aboard a starship, that is not necessary. We are all capable of exercising self-control. You will refrain from using them.
Now just a minute.
We are involved in a very serious and potentially dangerous situation.
I'm sure that whatever it is seems very important to you. My situation is far more critical.
I do not think you are fully aware of your situation, or the time which has passed.

Believe me, I'm fully cognizant of where I am, and when. It is simply that I have more to protect than a man in your position could possibly imagine. No offense, but a military career has never been considered upwardly mobile. I must contact my lawyer.
Your lawyer has been dead for centuries.
Yes, of course I know that, but he was a full partner with a very important firm. Rest assured the firm is still operating.

That's what this is all about... A lot has changed in three hundred years. People are no longer obsessed with the accumulation of "things". We have eliminated hunger, want, the need for possessions. We have grown out of our infancy.
You've got it wrong. It's never been about "possessions" - it's about power.
Power to do what?
To control your life, your destiny.
That kind of control is an illusion.
Really -- I'm here aren't I? I should be dead and I'm not. That's what money did for me. That's the kind of power I'm talking about.
What is it?
I don't know. It just started and I can't stop. I keep thinking about my boys.
Counselor Troi, report to the guest lounge.
Captain, we are approaching Science Station Delta Zero-Five.
Slow to impulse... I'm on my way.
Say, Captain -- I need to see that pretty Doctor of yours.
I will inform her.
Captain. I didn't mean to come on so strong. I've built my life on knowing what's going on. For the first time -- I'm completely out of touch -- it makes me crazy. Can you understand?
It's the first thing you've said that I do understand. I'll see what I can do. But please... stay off the com panel.
Counselor, get those people under control. We cannot afford this continuing distraction.
Yes, sir.
Hello -- my name is Deanna.
They sent you here to settle me down.
I'm the ship's counselor and I thought you might want to talk.
The local shrink.
I'm sorry, I do not know that term.
It doesn't matter.
You are feeling profoundly sad.

Can't stop crying. I miss my sons, and then I think... I'm here, but they are gone. Donald -- he's my husband. I love that man but, good intentions aside, he'd mess up a free lunch. Why in the world he ever decided to do this...
He must have thought you would have wanted it.

I can tell you exactly what happened. He couldn't think about going on alone. I died, but he couldn't face it. So he figured if he had me frozen, then in his mind I wasn't really gone. Crazy, huh? But you have to know Donald.
I'm in a world of strangers. I wish I knew what happened to my children. Did they get married, did they have kids...
Let's see if we can find out.
Computer - this is Counselor Troi. Request personal history on... What are their names?
Tommy -- he's eight, and Eddie's five.
Full names -- Date and place of birth.
They were born in Secaucus - that's in Jersey. Can this really work? Can this tell me what happened to them?
There has to be a record somewhere. There is a good chance we can find it.
Whether we do or not, thank you for... trying. Date of birth. Tommy was born February seventeenth...
I just got to have a little something to jump start the morning -- and a little something else to shut down the night.
You have no medical need.
It's not a question of "need," darlin'. It's a matter of survival.
Sorry.
Not to worry -- ol' Watosh will scuffle along the best way he can.
How do I get a hold of the ol' boy with the marinie face?
I beg your pardon?
What's his name... that android fella.
Lieutenant Commander Data?
That's the one.
I'll let him know you want to see him.
Much obliged. You sure are the prettiest little doctor I ever saw.
Much obliged.
Amazing. It's all right there.
Yes, ten generations of your progeny.
Everyone I ever knew is dead. Would you mind... I'd like to be alone.
No, not at all.
You asked to see me.
I'm about to go out of my mind for something to do. Sittin' alone drinkin' don't get it. What say you and me put together a little party.
A celebration?
Naw... nothin' that fancy -- just some folks, some suds, and some sounds. Hell it ain't nothin' but somethin' to do. Whatdeya think?
I will ask the captain.
Great -- you do that...
Query. You do not seem to be having as much difficulty adjusting to your current circumstances as are the others.
You mean being here -- on this tub -- four hundred years from where I started? Heck -- it's the same dance, just a different tune. You think anyone 'round here's got a guitar I could borrow?
No, but the computer can replicate such an instrument.
I was kind of hopin' to get one while I still remember the chords.
Commander Data -- we are approaching the Neutral Zone. Report to the bridge.
I must leave.
What's this "Neutral Zone?"
A buffer between the Romulan Empire and the Federation.
Why does that make me nervous?
I do not know.
We won't be inviting these Romulans to our party, will we?
No, it would not be appropriate.
Captain's log, supplemental. We have arrived at the edge of the Neutral Zone. We will now have an opportunity to learn firsthand what happened to our distant outposts.
There is nothing left of Outpost Delta Zero-Five.
It must have been one hell of an explosion.
Sensors indicate no evidence of a conventional attack.
There is nothing left.
Can you determine what happened?
The outpost was not just destroyed, it is as though some great force just scooped it off the face of the planet.
Could it have been a natural phenomenon?
Insufficient information.
Geordi, set a course for the next closest station.
Aye, sir.
I just can't believe this. When that android fella said you could duplicate this baby, I didn't dream you'd do such a bang-up job... You like country?
Excuse me?
Picking and strummin', son. What about rock?
What about rock?
What's the matter, kid? You look like you're staring at a ghost.
Well, sir, you were dead for over three-hundred years...
How 'bout rhythm and blues? That comes back every decade or so.
What was it like?... I mean, can you remember...
What? Bein' dead? Not really, but then again there wasn't a whole lot happening.
Why did you do it? Was there something left undone... something you have to finish?
Nope. Just curiosity... Another adventure... Simply wanted to see what was going on.
We are approaching Tarod Nine.
The condition is identical, Captain.
Everyone and everything is gone.
Captain, I strongly recommend that we go to Red Alert. If the Romulans have improved their cloaking device, and we'd be fools to think they haven't, we should assume a more defensive posture.
I agree, Captain. I recommend we go immediately to battle stations.
I appreciate your concern and advice, but this is not the time for rash actions. We are still investigating.
There are three other stations in this sector which we need to visit. Let's proceed in a calm and orderly manner.
If not "battle stations," may I at least bring the ship to Yellow Alert?
Yes, Number One. That would be prudent.
Thank you.
So, what is it that you want?
I've spent my career being able to tell when the other guy's mouth is dry. There is something going on. Something serious. The tension level on this ship has jumped up.
Even if you're right, what can we do about it? And besides, these old boys don't need us to tell them where the bear sits.
Lookie here what that young fella made for me.
How did he do that?
He called it a pattern replication. It plays real good, too.
I'm trying to tell you that there is a situation developing on this vessel which affects us, and all you can talk about is that stupid guitar!
These folks don't need us swimming in their soup, so why don't you just relax and let them do their jobs?
That may be all right for you, but I am not willing to allow my fate to be decided by others. I at least want to know what is going on.
How are you planning to do that?
He needs help. I think he's dying.
What the hell are you doing?
I'm going to find out what's going on.
Ah... let's see. Ah... I want to go to a... the... ah... (he shrugs; then to himself:) Where would the captain be?
Captain Picard is located on the Main Bridge.
Then, take me to the Main Bridge.
Captain, my sensors indicate a disturbance. It is large and moving, but I cannot get a positive lock nor can I get it on the viewscreen.
Shields up.
Aye, sir.
Captain, I recommend we transfer all power to phasers, and arm the photon torpedos.
Wait. If that is a Romulan ship, it will read our intent. We will be forcing them to take a similar posture. We are not out here to engage in battles; we are explorers.
Captain, there is sufficient evidence. Outposts have been destroyed... Countless lives have been lost.
I have a positive lock... It's disengaging its cloaking device.
They are vulnerable for an instant as they become visible.
Captain, this may be our only chance.
I've lost them.
Are your sensors picking up anything? You should be detecting a disturbance.
Negative.
We wanted to know if they have improved their cloaking device -- I guess we have our answer.
They were trying to determine our intent... They wanted to see if we would fire.
Who the hell are they?
Get that man off the bridge... now.
I'm not going anywhere.
Captain, they're back.
On screen.
Amazing. I never thought I would ever see a Romulan ship -- not this close.
The last encounter was decades ago and cost thousands of lives.
I can believe that.
Stay calm, everyone.

Captain, these are Romulans -- they are without honor. They killed my parents in an attack on Khitomer at a time when they were supposed to be our allies. They believe humans and Klingons are a waste of skin, so inferior as to be unworthy of any consideration.
Lieutenant, keep your emotions under control. Open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open.
Romulan vessel, this is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the USS Enterprise.
Sensors indicate all of their systems are armed.
But they have not fired.
Let's try them again.
Hailing frequencies are still open.
Romulan vessel, this is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the USS Enterprise.
I am Commander Tebok.
You have crossed the Neutral Zone. This is Federation territory.
It was necessary.
It could be viewed as an act of aggression.
If our intent was aggression, you would not now be here.
If we go to war, let us be sure it is for the right reason. We are here because our outposts, which border the Neutral Zone, were also attacked.
Destroyed in the exact same manner as your own.
What right did they have to enter Federation space?
Silence your dog, Captain.
Lieutenant Worf's question is valid.
Even to ask such a question implies that we need permission; we do not.
Do you think we attacked your outposts?
Once we realized the level of destruction, we knew it could not have been you.
Who is responsible?
They haven't a clue.
They're hoping you know, but they're too arrogant to ask.
You're out of line, Mister.
Yes, but correct in his assessment.
We do not know who is responsible... Why entire outposts on both sides were carried off.
I would like to offer a proposal.
An alliance? Between the Romulans and the Federation?
Nothing so grandiose -- just this. Cooperation... whoever or whatever did this is more powerful than either of us.
Agreed.
On this one issue, and only if it is convenient and something we consider appropriate at the time.

Captain Picard, because your actions are those of a thoughtful man who is neither rash nor easily provoked, I tell you this. More urgent matters have caused our absence, and witness the results. Outposts destroyed, evidence of the Federation everywhere. We have been negligent, but no more.
We have made some progress in our relations... let's not ruin that with unnecessary posturing.
Your presence is not wanted. Do you understand my meaning? We are back!
I think our lives just became a lot more complicated.
Get him off my bridge.
I have found something.
I have been able to locate a family living outside of Indianapolis. The man's name is Thomas Raymond.
That's my son's name. My son's name is Tommy.
Computer -- let us see Thomas Raymond.
Oh, my God... It's Donald... that's my husband.
Actually, it's your great, great, great, great, great grandson.
He's the spitting image.
I have his address. When you get back to Earth, you could go and see him.
But... I will still be out of time. A relic.
Perhaps. But it's a place to start. He is after all, family.
There's no denying that.
Here is what I propose. You can't remain on the Enterprise. We have arranged to rendezvous with the USS Charleston, bound for Earth. You will be delivered there.
And then what will happen to us? There's no trace of my money -- my office is gone -- what will I do? How will I live?
This is the twenty-fourth century. Those material needs no longer exist.
Then what's the challenge?
To improve yourself... enrich yourself. Enjoy it, Mister Offenhouse.
Well, one good thing -- since everybody's forgotten everything I ever did... it'll all be brand spankin' new. Hell, I'll be a bigger hit than I ever was.
Perhaps so, anything is possible.
What say, son -- you'd make a hell of a sideman.
That offer does present a certain fascination.
I have plotted a course to intercept the Charleston, sir, but they have informed me that they will be making an extended stop at Arloff Nine.
Your point, Lieutenant?
At warp eight, we could have our guests at Starbase Thirty-Nine Sierra in five days. It would cut months off their journey.
They will benefit from the extended time. It will allow them to acclimate before arriving at Earth.
It's a pity we can't take them ourselves. Having them on board has been like a visit from the past.
That would take us in the wrong direction. Our mission is to go forward and it has just begun. Set velocity at warp six, Mister La Forge.
Aye, sir... warp six.
There is still much to do... and still so much to learn. Mister La Forge... Engage.

Captain's log, Stardate 46682.4. The Enterprise is docked at the Remmler Array, where it will undergo a routine procedure to eliminate accumulated baryon particles. In preparation for the sweep, we are evacuating the ship.
Captain... we're still behind schedule on decks seven and eight. Shall I tell Arkaria Base there'll be a delay?
No. Open up the Transporters in Cargo Bay Two and divert everyone from deck seven there. That should get us back on track.
Right.

Captain... Arkaria Base does not have the medical storage units I requested. I have seven living tissue samples that won't survive the baryon sweep anymore than you or I would. I've tried to reason with them, but --
Have Mister LaForge transport a stasis unit from the astrophysics lab. You should be able to convert it to store tissue samples.
Thank you.
Captain... I was just heading for deck seven. I've put the auto-shutdown sequence on hold until we get back on schedule.
I think we can resume the sequence. Counselor Troi is taking care of the situation on deck seven.
Aye, sir.
Captain.
Mister Data. Bridge.
It has been quite a day, has it not?
Yes it has.
However, a change of routine is often invigorating and can be a welcome diversion after a long assignment.
Exactly.
I understand that Arkaria has some very interesting weather patterns.
Data -- are you alright?
Yes, sir. I was attempting to fill a silent moment with non-relevant conversation.
Small talk?
Yes, sir. I have found that humans often make "small talk" during awkward moments. Therefore, I have written a new subroutine designed for that purpose. How did I do?

Perhaps it was a little too... non-relevant. However, if you're interested in small talk keep your eye on Commander Hutchinson during the reception this afternoon... (not looking forward to it) ... he's a master.
Thank you sir, I will.
After you...
No sir. I believe you spoke first.
We're running out of time, gentlemen. Mister Worf?
The computer needs your authorization to disable command functions during the baryon sweep.
Are we ready, Mister La Forge?
Almost. I've requested some additional field diverters for the computer core and the Bridge and they haven't been installed yet.
Additional units?

We've logged more warp hours in five years than most ships do in ten, so our baryon particle levels are pretty high. I'm a little worried that when the Remmler Array starts sweeping the ship it might have to use a stronger beam than normal to clear out all the radiation.
And that might overload the field diverters protecting our key systems. How long until the new ones are in place?
I'd say another twenty minutes.
Very well. Computer, disable all command functions in thirty minutes. Authorization: Picard gamma-six-zero-seven-three.
Authorization acknowledged.
Incoming message, Captain. It's the station administrator, Mister Orton.
In my Ready Room.
Sir. Request permission to be excused from Commander Hutchinson's... reception.
Permission granted. I only wish I could excuse myself as well.
Captain, permission to --
Sorry, Mister LaForge... I can't excuse the entire senior staff. Worf beat you to it.
Go ahead, Mister Orton.
Captain, if you're on schedule, I'd like to confirm that we'll begin the baryon sweep at fifteen hundred hours -- approximately one hour from now.
Confirmed.
Commander Hutchinson also wanted me to make sure that you'll be able to attend his reception this afternoon.
Tell him... I'm looking forward to it.
He'll be delighted to hear that. Arkaria Base out.
Tell Arkaria base that we're almost finished here...
We're going to need two more conduits...
I need to run a diagnostic on the diverter...
Get the diverter aligned so that we can begin the isolation procedure.
Where's the ODN interface?
Beverly! Lovely as ever... how do you manage it?
It's good to see you again.

It's been far too long -- what is it, four years? Now I want to hear all about what happened after you left Starfleet Medical. And I have so much to tell you. Oh, that must be Commander Riker. Excuse me, won't you?
Of course.
You must be Wil Riker.
I guess I must.
Calvin Hutchinson -- call me Hutch. Calvin -- awful name, I've never forgiven my parents. As soon as I saw you, I knew you had to be the Enterprise's first officer.
Oh?
Of course. Your reputation proceeds you -- flashing blue eyes, square jaw... quite the ladies man I hear. Now don't be modest, Wil -- may I call you Wil?
Uh, sure.

I've also heard that you're a musician. I hope you'll play something for us. It's not often that I get a chance to entertain the command crew of the flagship... and speaking of command, hello Captain Picard.
Commander.
I was just telling your first officer what a real pleasure it is to have you all...
It is very good to see you both again. May I call you Beverly? -- Beverly, do you find the mean temperature here on Arkaria to be slightly above normal for human comfort levels?
I have found that most humans prefer a temperature of twenty-one degrees C in order to operate most efficiently. However, there are some cultures which actually...
... I tell you, you've never seen anything like it. There were thousands of these creatures... the whole northern sky turned dark.
Geordi! Deanna! I don't believe you've met our host. Allow me to introduce Commander Geordi La Forge, Counselor Deanna Troi. This is Commander Hutchinson.
Hutch.
Hello.
Hello.
I was just telling your captain about some of the fascinating sights here on Arkaria. Is either of you interested in ornithology?
Uh... well...
The mating habits of the Arkarian horn fowl are quite interesting. If the weather were better, we could take horses to the southern promontory and visit the nesting grounds.
Horses?
Yes... there's a network of trails through the plains. Unfortunately, they aren't very pleasant right now... muddy, cold. Not a soul for kilometers.
That sounds... perfect. How long until the baryon sweep begins on the Enterprise?
At least twenty-five minutes.
Then I'll have time to get my saddle.
Your... saddle?
Yes. A saddle is a very personal thing. It has to be broken in... worn... cared for...
You keep a saddle... on the Enterprise?
Yes. I've had it since the Academy. I never know when I'll have the opportunity to ride.
I see.
It's perfectly normal. Most serious riders have their own saddles.
Of course.
Yes, sir.
Absolutely.
If you'll excuse me.
An amazing man. He reminds me of another officer I knew many years ago... a Captain Edwell. Now he was fascinating... born on Gaspra Seven but you wouldn't know it from the way he looked...
Auto-shutdown sequence in progress. Defensive systems off-line. Baryon sweep begins in eight minutes.
What are you doing?
Somone left this ODN junction box open. I thought your crew was supposed to leave the ship once the field diverters were in place.
The diverters have to be synchronized. I was laser-bonding a backup link.
I see. Well, I suppose I'd better let you finish up so you can get off the ship.
Wait a minute --
Auto shut-down sequence in progress. Inertial dampers off-line. Baryon sweep begins in six minutes.
Auto shut-down sequence in progress. Life support off-line. Baryon sweep begins in three minutes.
We still have to by-pass the magnetic containment conduit.
That should be down on deck thirty.
Get Pomet started on it right away.
Auto shut-down sequence in progress. Primary power off-line in one minute.
Primary power off-line in thirty seconds.
Final warning. Primary power off-line in ten seconds...

I find it fascinating that your family chose to drop the prefix "Pel" from your surname. It was my understanding that "Pel Orton" would be considered a more noble appellation on Arkaria than simply Orton.
Yes.
Perhaps the recent Arkarian trend toward a more egalitarian society is partly responsible.
Perhaps.
The crew of the Magellan actually put on a talent show here. Captain Conklin did a poetry reading, if you can imagine that.
I'm trying to.
Did I ever tell you how I came to be stationed here? It's a fascinating story.
You see, I was serving on Admiral Mitchell's staff on Starbase ninety-seven -- awful place, by the way --
Hutch. Have you met our Commander Data?
Why no, I don't think so.
... there are several cultures in this sector with remarkably similar etymological histories --
Data, allow me to introduce our host. This is Commander Hutchinson -- call him Hutch. This is our second officer, Commander Data.
A pleasure.
The pleasure is mine. I have been meaning to compliment you on your choice of colors here.
You really think so? It wasn't easy to make the final decision, let me tell you.
I am sure of that. The light in this room makes color selection exceptionally problematic.
Precisely.
Thank you.
You're welcome. I'm not sure which one to feel sorry for.
Mister Orton?
If you'll excuse me, Commander.
Geordi... what happened to the Captain?
He went back to the ship to get his saddle.
His saddle?
Any serious rider would have his own saddle.
Oh.
He probably went right to the stables. I bet he's ten kilometers from here already.
(glances at Hutchinson & Data) Lucky him.
Kelsey to Devor. Devor, this is Kelsey. Reply.
Devor, do you read me? Kelsey to Kiros.
This is Kiros.
Devor isn't responding. There must be too much interference from the baryon sweep. Go find him and see if he finished by-passing the regulator on deck seven, then meet us in Main Engineering.
Understood.
Who are you? What are you doing on my ship.
The baryon sweep uses a high-frequency plasma field. That phaser won't work.
You're probably right.
But I'm willing to bet that this will.
What's going on in Main Engineering?
I suggest you cooperate.
You're Starfleet... you won't kill me.
Are you sure?
I guess you're right.
... yes, but Tyrellian laser-art is very similar in form and composition.
Oh, of course. Funny you should mention that. I used to be stationed on Tyrellia.
Really? There are five Tyrellians currently serving aboard the Enterprise.
Fascinating. Not many people know this, but Tyrellia is one of only three known inhabited worlds without a magnetic pole.
I was aware of that. Are you aware that Tyrellia is also one of seven known planets...
Are they still at it?
Non-stop. I have to admit it has a sort of strange fascination... I mean, how long can two people talk about... nothing?
Is something wrong?
Uh... I don't know. I'm getting a weird energy reading from your table.
I'm sure it's nothing serious. Perhaps the heating element under the tray is malfunctioning.
Maybe I should take a look at it.
I'm sure we can handle this, whatever it is, Commander. There's no need to concern yourself.
I really think I should look at that heating element. If it overloads under --
It's all right.
What's that all about?
We'll look into it. You don't have to concern yourself.
Orton, now!
Stay right where you are.
Reduce the plasma pressure to zero point six percent nominal.
Zero point six.
How does the conduit look?
It's clear.
All right. The main plasma flow is shunted to the aft conduit. We're ready up here.
Okay. That should do it. I think.
Be sure, Neil.
Uh... yes... yes, that does it. (calls over his shoulder) All right... transfer five hundred milligrams from the reserve system to the engine core.
Perfect.
Adequate. Disable the containment overrides and get the interlocks off the magnetic seal.
Right.
Pomet, prepare the transport assembly. Keep watching the power flow, it might...
Keep working.
Where did he come from?
I found him on deck seven.
Who are you?
My name is Mott. I'm... the barber.
The barber? What the hell are you doing here? Everyone was supposed to be evacuated to the surface.
I... I know. But, I wanted to go riding and I didn't have my saddle, so I came back --
Your saddle?
That's right. I left it in the corridor on deck seven. When the power went off, I got lost and didn't know where to go so --
All right, shut up. Any sign of Devor?
No.
If he's off looting at a time like this... All right, go find him and make sure nothing's wrong. Salter. Get over here and keep an eye on our... barber.
Sit down.
Sure, okay. You don't need to point that at me.
Just do what I tell you, and you won't have to worry.
How long until you're ready?
Forty, maybe fifty minutes.
The baryon sweep hits this compartment in thirty minutes.
The field diverter will protect us.
It's not us I'm worried about, it's that storage unit. I want the trilithium resin...
... in there and secured before the sweep gets here. I don't want to take any chances.
Understood.
They haven't tried to communicate with the outside.
No demands, no political statements, no theft... they must want something.
Orton is not as calm as he looks. He's very agitated and nervous... as if something's gone wrong.
It is possible that Geordi upset their timetable when he saw the hidden weapons.
Orton could be improvising... maybe he didn't plan to take us hostage this early... so now he doesn't know what to do...
If they do not have a plan for this contingency, we may have the initiative.
Maybe, but we have to think of a way to use it...
How's Geordi?
There's no permanent damage. I've adjusted the optical transducer in his VISOR to block some of the pain receptors in his brain, but it's only partially effective.
What about Hutchinson?
There was nothing I could do for him. I still need to get Geordi to a medical facility.
I doubt he'll agree to that. If we told him Geordi was dying he might give us access to a medical kit... maybe we could make a weapon from some of the tools...
Perhaps we can use the VISOR as a weapon. If the optical transducer were modified, it may be possible to generate a hypersonic pulse.
A hypersonic pulse would overload the audio receptors of everyone in the room. It would cause immediate unconsciousness.
Can you make the adjustments to the VISOR by yourself? It's going to look suspicious if both of you go over there.
I'll try... Geordi may have to help me through some of it.
All right... try to keep it casual. Let us know when you're ready.
Ready.
Begin draining the trilithium at one hundred milligrams per minute.
Neil, what's going on!?
The primary inducer is completely fused. There's no way to fix it. Without the diverter, we don't have any protection from the baryon sweep.
I know that. How long until the baryon sweep hits this section?
About twelve minutes. We should go to Ten Forward, it's the last place on the ship that'll be swept by the baryon field.
All right, we're leaving. But we're taking the trilithium with us.
What? The storage unit wasn't designed to be portable. We can't just start hauling it through the ship --
I'll... I'll try to make some modifications.
Satler's dead... he ran into the baryon sweep.
And what about Mott?
I don't know. But I don't think he's a barber. I found this in the Jefferies Tube.
Kelsey to Kiros.
This is Kiros.
We have a problem. There's a Starfleet officer still aboard. He killed Satler and he may have killed Devor.
He also destroyed the diverter in Engineering so we have to leave here before the baryon sweep enters this section.
What about the trilithium resin?
We're taking it with us to Ten Forward.
There should be enough time before --
(firm, into communicator) Kelsey. Don't be a fool. You know better than to try moving that resin.
Mister Mott... or should I call you Lieutenant... Lieutenant Commander perhaps?
You may call me whatever you wish, but moving trilithium resin requires very specific equipment. You can't simply improvise something.
I wouldn't need to improvise if you hadn't damaged our field diverter.
But if you're so concerned about the trilithium, I suggest you stop interfering with us -- before you set off an explosion that would destroy the Enterprise... and you.
I would rather destroy this ship than allow that material to fall into the hands of terrorists.
What makes you think I'm a terrorist?
Trilithium resin is a highly toxic waste material produced by our engines. There's no possible use for it except as a weapon.
You might be right, Mister Mott. But we've been planning this for a long time, and I doubt that you'll really be able to stop us... or even slow us down.
That's it... three hundred milligrams of trilithium.
I'm using a dynamic stabilizer to act as a control rod...
There. That should keep the resin stable enough for transport.
Don't look so tense, Neil. If something goes wrong, you won't have time to worry about it.
Let's go.
How much further?
Three more decks... then we take corridor fifteen-B all the way to Ten Forward.
What's wrong?
We have to find another way up.
That wasn't very clever, Mister Mott.
If you knew where we were, you should've attacked us. Now we'll just take another route... one you might not be able to predict.
There are only so many ways to Ten Forward... and Ten Forward is the only logical place to go if you want to stay ahead of the Baryon sweep.
That sweep is just as big a threat to you as it is to us. In fact, if I were you, Mister Mott, I'd be trying to find a way off this ship.
I plan on leaving the same way you do... on your ship.
What ship?
Come on, Kelsey. If you've been planning this for so long, you must have a way to get off the Enterprise and leave this system. I think there's a ship coming for you. And I plan to be on it.
It's a small ship, Mott... I don't think there's going to be room for both of us.
I'm sorry to hear that... I'll send your regrets.
How is he, Doctor?
He's in a lot of pain, but he should be fine. He needs some water.
We're almost ready. But when we set the VISOR to emit the hypersonic pulse, there'll be a short burst of light. We need a distraction.
They need a distraction.
How long?
A few seconds.
I think I can keep Orton busy for a few seconds.
I don't think Orton's in a talking mood, Wil.
You just have to know how to talk to him.
Orton, I think we should discuss this situation.
There's nothing to discuss. Sit down.
I think there's a lot to discuss. Can't we be reasonable here?
I'm not interested in hearing your hostage negotiation tactics, Commander.
It won't hurt you to listen, will it?
All right.
Thank you. Now the first thing I think we should discuss is this...
Well, Commander... Here's my response.
Put your weapon down... slowly.
Kelsey, this is Kiros. I'm on deck ten. I have Mott.
Is he alive?
Yes.
Good. Meet us at intersection forty-one.
Understood.
Move.
Give me the trilithium.
How... how much farther do we have to go?
Not far. With all the modifications you made to this unit, will we have any trouble removing the trilithium?
No... you just remove the control rod and then drain the unit... there shouldn't be any problem.
That's all I wanted to know.
Well... not as clever as you thought. Where's Pomet?
He shot him with some kind of arrow.
He's not dead.
Well, he will be soon. The baryon sweep's nearly here and we don't have time to go back for him.
What about Neil?
The sweep got him. Let's go. And you can lead, Mister Mott. That way if we come to any more of your little surprises, you'll be sure to let us know.
I thought you were going to talk with him.
I did. He just didn't like what I had to say.
That was a perimeter warning from the Remmler Array. A small ship is approaching. (beat as he watches Orton) I believe Mister Orton has just dropped the defense shields.
This has to be what they've been waiting for.
Data, you're going to be the only one unaffected by the hypersonic burst. As soon as everyone's unconscious, you've got to get to the computer panel and stop that ship somehow.
I will try, sir.
Kelsey -- perhaps we can work out a deal.
You're the only one who needs a deal, Mott.
My name's not Mott. It's Jean-Luc Picard.
Captain Picard... this is all beginning to make sense...
Leave the trilithium here and take me with you. You can use me as a hostage instead of threatening --
I'm not a terrorist Captain, and I don't have a political agenda... But I know some people who do have agendas... and who are very interested in this little container.
Profit. This is all about profit.
I prefer to think of it as commerce.
Open the door.
Now go through... slowly.
(touches her communicator) I guess, I'll be the one to send your regrets.
Arkaria base, this is Captain Picard. Deactivate the baryon sweep. This is Captain Picard on the Enterprise. Deactivate the baryon sweep immediately.
Data to Captain Picard... do you read me Captain?
Picard here.
Are you all right, Captain?
Yes.
Sir, an unidentified scout ship has just beamed someone off the Enterprise. Do you know anything about it?
I know they won't get very far.
Hold still... you've got a nasty cut here...
(to Troi, very concerned) Any luck?
I'm sorry, Captain. I don't know what could've happened to it.
I've had three security teams search deck seven and they couldn't find anything.
Hold still. I can't heal this cleanly if you keep fidgeting.
I found it, Captain. Someone put it in a maintenance locker.
Thank you.
You keep a saddle on board?
Worf, I'm surprised at you...
Any experienced rider would naturally have his own saddle.
It's perfectly normal.
Of course.
It came in very handy. I just wish I'd had a chance to use it on a horse.

Captain's Log, Stardate 46915.2. The Enterprise is orbiting Nervala Four, waiting for an opportunity to retrieve scientific data left there by Starfleet researchers when they were forced to evacuate eight years ago.
Thank you... thank you very much.
Any requests tonight?
Night Bird.
Anyone?
Night Bird!
Ladies and Gentlemen... Night Bird.
What was that all about?
Wil's been trying to get this piece right for ten years now. He's never made it through the solo.
Remember that dance recital I told you I was doing?
Next week.
You're dis-invited.
Here it comes.
Data to Commander Riker.
Riker, here.
Commander, you are needed on the Bridge.
On my way.
Saved by the bell...
You wanted to see me, Data?
Yes, sir. It appears that we will be able to transport to the surface sooner than we anticipated.
Is the planet's distortion field de-phasing sooner than you predicted?
No, sir. But using the Potemkin's transport logs from the original evacuation, Commander La Forge and I were able to modify the Transporters.
So we can beam through higher distortion levels.
The Transporters are now considerably more efficient than those used on the Potemkin eight years ago.
Glad to hear it. I almost didn't make it off the surface that day. When can we get started?
Ninety-seven minutes.
How long will the transport window last?
Twenty-six minutes. After that, the distortion field will re-phase.
That doesn't give us much time to retrieve the database.
The planet's proximity to its sun will create two additional transport windows in the next three days.
Let's hope that's enough.
It will have to be. The next transport window will not occur for another eight years, when the planet's orbit brings it close enough to the sun to de-phase the distortion field.
Notify the Away Team we're going in ahead of schedule; I'll tell the Captain.
How long until the transport window opens?
Fourteen seconds.
Let's get in position.
Whenever you're ready, Commander.
Energize.
This isn't how I remember it; the place was a mess when we left.
Commander...
Someone's been here...
A vessel could have gotten caught in the distortion field and crashed. The survivors may have taken shelter here.
Commander, someone is approaching... a humanoid. Forty meters due east and closing.
Who are you?
Who are you?
Commander William Riker of the Federation Starship Enterprise.
That's not possible. I'm Wil Riker.
May I ask how you got here?
Eight years ago, I led a team to evacuate this station.
What ship were you on?
The Potemkin.
Why did you not return to the Potemkin with the others?
I was the last one out. The distortion field must have interfered with the transport; they lost their signal lock on me. When I tried to contact the ship, I couldn't get through the interference.
Check with Starfleet; I'm sure they recorded me lost that day.
That's not what happened. I was the last one out... but I made it back to the Potemkin.
You don't believe me.
It's not that we don't believe you; it's just hard to see how both our stories could be true. Would you be willing to let our Doctor check you out?
Of course.
Lieutenant Worf, take him to Sickbay. Notify the Captain as soon as you're aboard.
Worf to Enterprise. Two to beam up.
Let's get to work.
Looks like you fractured your arm a few years ago.
I was underneath the station making repairs when an earthquake hit -- I got caught in a rockslide. I had to set it myself.
Captain Jean-Luc Picard.
Lieutenant Wil Riker, sir.
If you are Wil Riker, if there are two of you... then something extraordinary has occurred. I hope you understand our need to verify your claim.
Yes, sir.
Genetically, he's indistinguishable from Commander Riker.
Could some sort of cloning be involved?
I don't think so, there's no genetic drift.
But that isn't conclusive.
That's why I compared their brain scans. Brain organization patterns are as unique as... fingerprints. Except for some minor differences, theirs are identical.
Can't brain patterns be cloned?
No. They're determined by experience, mostly in early childhood.
How could two men have shared the same childhood experiences? It doesn't make any sense.
Sir, I am Wil Riker. I don't know who or what made it back to the Potemkin that day, but it wasn't me.
Lieutenant -- my Chief Engineer is checking over the transport logs from the Potemkin. They may shed some light on what happened.
Yes, sir.
Don't worry, we'll get to the bottom of this.
In the meantime you'll be taken to quarters. Make yourself comfortable.
I will, sir. The replicators on the station stopped working a long time ago. It's been a while since I had a decent meal.
Doctor...

... apparently there was a massive energy surge in the distortion field around the planet just at the moment you tried to beam out. The Transporter Chief tried to compensate by initiating a second containment beam.
An interesting approach. He must have been planning to reintegrate the two patterns in the transport buffer.
Turns out he didn't have to. Commander Riker's pattern maintained its integrity with just the one containment beam -- he made it back to the ship just fine.
What happened to the second beam?
The Transporter Chief shut it down, but somehow... it was reflected back to the surface.
And another Wil Riker materialized there.
How could the second pattern have maintained its integrity?
The containment beam must have had the exact same phase differential as the distortion field.
Which one of us is... real?
Both. You were both re-materialized from a complete pattern.
Up to that moment, you were the same person.
But over the last eight years, you and...
-- Lieutenant Riker have lived very different lives. You're different people now.
For us, it's a little like meeting a close friend's twin. You can't help feeling that you know them... but of course you don't.
No matter how strange it may seem to us... there are now two Wil Rikers aboard this vessel. Getting used to the idea may take a while... especially for you, Wil.
I'll be all right, sir.
Lieutenant Riker will be here for a few days at least. We should do everything we can to make him feel comfortable and welcome.
That still leaves us with the problem of how to retrieve the database. The station's computer is only partially operational.
Many of its components have been removed. Apparently Lieutenant Riker used them to keep the station's radiation shield operational.
Can we repair it, at least enough to access the database?
Without knowing what he did, it'll be tough.
Maybe he could help?
He was alone down there a long time. I'm hesitant to send him back until he's been evaluated.
I'll talk to him.
Thank you, Counselor.
Come in.
Hello, Wil.
Imzadi...
Wil...
I thought I'd never see you again...
We need to talk.
You're here... on this ship... because of him.
No.
Commander Riker and I are friends, close friends; nothing more.
Wil -- why don't we sit down?
Do you remember the last time we saw each other?
Like yesterday. We spent the day at the Janaran falls, on Betazed.
It was the day before you started your tour on the Potemkin.
We were going to meet six weeks later, on Risa.
We never did.
I know.
What I mean is... Commander Riker and I never did.
You see... he earned a promotion very quickly.
I know. For exceptional valor during the evacuation of the research station on Nervala Four. I looked over his service record.
He chose to make his career a priority. There wasn't time for much of anything else.
We kept in touch... but we didn't see each other again until we were both posted to the Enterprise two years later.
By then, our feelings for each other had changed. We've served together for six years now... things never went back to the way they used to be.
I had a lot of time on my hands down there. There were days I felt so alone I thought I might lose my mind.
Do you know what got me through? Thinking that if I could hang on, one more day, maybe I'd be rescued... and I'd see you again.
Well... I guess things don't always turn out quite the way you expect them to.
I know this isn't what you were hoping for, but that doesn't mean you can't make a future for yourself.
For now, I think I'll just take things one day at a time.
Captain Picard wanted me to find out if you'd be willing to help us retrieve the station's database.
I reconfigured that computer system so many times they probably can't make heads or tails of it. I'd be happy to help.
Do you feel up to it?
Absolutely.
I'll tell the Captain.
Well... I have to go.
Deanna... I know it's been a long time since we were together; I know your feelings have changed. But...
Mine haven't. I can't just give up and accept that it's over... I want to be with you again.
Good night, Wil...
Phase distortion is dropping -- the second transport window will open in forty-two seconds.
How long will we have?
Thirty-six minutes, sir.
We are losing time. Lieutenant Riker should be here.
Computer, where is Lieutenant --
Cancel inquiry.
You were supposed to report here at eight hundred hours.
I'm sorry, I was --
I guess it's been a while since you had to punch a clock.
Let's go.
Energize.
I shut down most of the consoles to save power. I re-routed just about everything through here.
Check out the primary EPS coupling, see if you can get some power to the rest of these consoles.
I shunted the database to the main core underneath the station.
Can we access it from here?
There's been a lot of seismic activity over the years; if the servo-links were damaged, we may not be able to.
I'll try to tap into the command pathways. See if you can disable the file server.
I was thinking... we should probably let Dad know what's happened.
I'm sure he'll be thrilled to hear there are two of us now.
I don't know. He and I patched up a few things.
I've gotten by without talking to him for a long time. I'm not about to start now.
What made you contact him?
I didn't. He came to the Enterprise to brief me when I was offered the Aries.
What did he say when you turned down the chance to command your own ship?
He couldn't understand why I did it.
For once he and I agree on something.
The primary EPS coupling is fused. It will have to be replaced.
I've accessed the command pathways.
Let's see if that does the trick.
It's not working. The servo-link must be damaged. We're going to have to go under the station and access the core directly.
We have less than three minutes left.
Leave me here. If I start now, I'll be finished by the time the third window opens.
It's too dangerous. Our scans show the caverns are unstable.
I've been down there dozens of times; I know my way around.
We'll come back during the third window with a new EPS coupling and try to access the core from another console up here.
Riker to Enterprise.
Enterprise, here.
We're ready to beam up.
You go ahead; I'll be finished by the time you get back.
Hold it --
I gave you an order, Lieutenant.
Computer -- valerian root tea, hot.
Meet me in Transporter Room Three at nineteen hundred hours. It's important.
It pulses unendingly All through the night; Seek out the crystal That powers our flight.
Can I help you with something, Counselor?
No -- thanks, anyway.
What the future holds No one can know But forward we look And Forward you go...
The Janaran falls...
I remember. Where did you get this?
I made it... a few years ago, down on the station.
You made this?
You should have seen the first two. It took me a while to get a fine enough beam from the phaser.
It's lovely. Thank you.
Do you have time to sit and talk for a while?
I wanted to remember... our last night together.
How does it feel being with people again?
Great... A little strange... For a long time, I did whatever I wanted, whenever I wanted; it's hard to get used to taking orders again.
I can imagine.
I guess I'm going to have to if I want to get my career going.
Is that what you've decided to do?
Don't you remember? How I wanted to make Captain by the time I was thirty-five?
I'm a little behind schedule, I'll admit.
It's good that you don't feel... set back.
I do. But I promised myself that if I ever got out of there, I'd make up for lost time.
Things are a little more complicated than I thought they'd be... but I'm not going to let anything stop me from getting what I want.
Thanks.

I can't tell you how many times I thought about you... about us. The first few weeks after the evacuation, I was sure they'd find a way to get through the distortion field and come back for me. I even thought we'd meet on Risa like we planned. But the days kept going by and nobody came. Then I realized why. They thought I'd been killed in the beam out. As far as anyone knew, there was no one to come back for. I figured they probably held a memorial service for me. Somehow... it made me feel better.
I can understand that.
You were there... all in black. Very flattering on you, by the way.
I'm sure I looked terrible -- my eyes all red and swollen from crying.

Sometimes I'd look up into the sky and think that maybe, if I tried hard enough, I could somehow make you... feel my presence. I thought that if I could let you know I was still alive... maybe you'd wait for me. I know it's crazy, but there were a few times that... that I could've sworn --
What am I talking about?
The other day, when I told you how Commander Riker and I didn't meet on Risa... what I didn't say was how disappointed I was.
You didn't have to. I knew.

I started hearing from him less and less... I knew his career was taking him away from me, but I didn't want to believe it was over. I spent a lot of time thinking about him, wondering where he was, what he was doing.
Sometimes I'd look up into the sky... and imagine that he knew, that he could sense me thinking about him.
Who knows? Maybe one night... you and I were both looking up at the same star. You were thinking about me... and in a way, I was thinking about you.
You wanted to see me, Sir?
Yes, Number One. Come in.
Lieutenant Riker came to see me about the away mission.
He believes the only way to retrieve the database is by directly accessing the main core underneath the station.
Seismic activity has made the caverns very unstable. In my opinion, it's too risky.
He said he'd been down there quite recently; he seems confident it can be done safely.
There's a good chance we can retrieve the database from one of the consoles inside the station.
But if that doesn't work, it'll be eight years before we get another chance.
Lieutenant Riker's plan is more dangerous, but I'll admit, it has a better chance of succeeding.
Given the importance of this data, I think it's worth the risk.
I'll look over the schematics and draw up a mission plan.
I'm sure Lieutenant Riker would be happy to help you with that.
I'll talk to him.
Lieutenant.
Sir.
I just spoke with the Captain about your mission recommendation. I'd appreciate it if next time you came to me first.
I tried to, yesterday on the station. You wouldn't hear me out.
I heard you, Lieutenant. And I rejected your plan.
May I ask what the Captain decided?
He's going with your recommendation, but that's not the point.
Isn't it?

If you think I'm coming down on you because the Captain overruled me, think again. I happen to disagree with his decision, but he's my commanding officer and I follow his orders. Just so there's no confusion, I'm your commanding officer and I expect you to do the same. If you can't, then you don't have a place on my Away Team.
Yes, sir.
We're meeting in the Observation lounge at fourteen hundred hours to draw up a mission plan.
... we stayed in Ten Forward talking for hours.
What happened then?
He walked me to my quarters.
What happened then?
Beverly --
I'm just asking.
It's been over between Wil and me for a long time.
He's not Wil. He is, but -- you know what I mean.
I do. But... it's hard for me to separate my feelings for them.
Deanna... just because things turned out the way they did between you and Commander Riker... that doesn't mean you shouldn't let things with Lieutenant Riker take their own course.
I should have known you'd encourage me.
Isn't that why you brought it up?
Well... I think I'll call it a day.
Beverly.
Bye.
Is that some form of tai-chi-chuan?
They're Klingon exercises, actually. Lieutenant Worf has been teaching a class.
The forms are very similar.
Do that last move again.
You just did the KoH-man-ara.
In tai-chi-chuan, it's called the crane block.
I had no idea they were so similar.
Let's try something else.
Very nice. Worf's a good teacher.
Hello, Wil.
Deanna...
I wanted to talk to you about something.
If you want to be with him... you don't have to ask my permission.
There's a certain look in your eyes. I know... you used to have it for me.
We've both had relationships with other people before; but this is different.
I didn't know how you would feel about it.
Flattered. Sort of.
It must be very strange for you. I know it is for me.
Ever since he came aboard... I keep finding myself thinking about... the choices you and I made.
Me too.
Just do one thing for me... be careful.
Wil... I know you and he have had some problems --
We have. But that's not what I'm talking about.
If he'd made it off that planet instead of me... don't you think he would have made the same choices I did?
I just don't want you to get hurt... again.
Two pair.
Three of a kind.
I'd like to thank you both for your very generous contributions.
Come in.
I thought -- you'd be alone. Excuse me.
Why don't you join us?
Why not?
The game is five card draw, no limit.
Lieutenant?
Three.
Mister Worf?
Four.
None for me.
The dealer will take two.
You control the bet.
Fifty.
Fold.
I'm in.
You didn't take any cards -- you must be holding something. Why not make it sweeter?
No thanks.
Playing it safe?
You in?
I will see your fifty and call.
Staying in will cost you another hundred.
The dealer folds.
I spent too much time practicing in the mirror to be fooled by that face. You're bluffing.
If there's one thing I thought would be clear by now, it's that you and I play things a little differently.
We'll see who comes out on top.
I thought you didn't mind settling for second. Commander.
I've never settled for anything in my life. I've made choices that some people may not understand, but I know what I want -- and I know what I've got. You'd be lucky to do as well. Lieutenant.
I'll see your hundred and call.
Three hundred.
Now I know you're bluffing.
Are you in or not?
Why don't we just get this over with? I'll match your three, and raise you whatever you have left.
Well?
Take it. You win.
You were dealt the better hand, Commander... all the way around.
Come in.
I'm sorry to just drop by like this... but there's something important I need to talk to you about.
Captain Picard made some inquiries -- he helped me find a posting on the Gandhi.
Considering how long I've been out of commission, it's an amazing opportunity.
When would you leave?
About a week.
I see.
Deanna...
After I've served on the ship for six months, I'll be eligible to bring family aboard.
If we got married...
You said those exact words to me once before... when you first went to serve on the Potemkin.
I remember. I got held up for a while.
But if you hadn't... what would have happened between us?
I wouldn't've made the mistake of letting you go. I know that much.
I don't know if I can believe that.
It took me a long time to get over what happened between Commander Riker and me. I don't know if I want to put myself in that position again.
I would never hurt you, Deanna.
It's not just that... I've worked hard to make a life for myself on the Enterprise. I'm happy here.
If the situation were different, I'd stay here. But I can't... not while he's aboard.
I know.
Are you saying it's over?
No.
I just don't know if I'm ready to give up my life here.
Maybe we both need time to think.
Good night.
Captain's Log, supplemental. The third transport window has opened and the Away Team is making their final attempt at retrieving the database.
Once we restore the servo-link, you can shunt the database up to this console.
Ready, Commander?
You're with me, Lieutenant.
I thought Commander Data's expertise in --
It doesn't take that much expertise to repair a servo-link. You and I can handle it.
I am curious about something, Lieutenant. If you met a double of yourself, would you find it difficult to interact with him?
I think so.
Why?
I am not... easy to get along with.
But Commander Riker and Lieutenant Riker are. Yet they seem to have trouble getting along with each another.
I have found that humans value their uniqueness, their sense that they are different from every one else. The existence of a double would preclude that feeling. Could that be the source of friction?
Perhaps it is more a matter of seeing something in your double... something you don't like about yourself.
There's the core over there.
Are you waiting for something?
Your order. Sir.
How would you like me to get there?
You've been down here "dozens" of times -- I'm sure you know the best way.
Yes, sir. I do.
